qas.question: When is it preferable to consider two group elements to be the same?

answers.text: irrelevant to the question whether a reflection has been performed

qas.question: What should not be considered when asking if a reflection has been performed?
What number sets are used to show how subgroups can be seen as translations of the larger group?

plausible_answers.text: if they differ by an element

qas.question: When are two group elements considered different?
In D4 the square can return to the r2 configuration by applying only what?

plausible_answers.text: whether a reflection has been performed

qas.question: What question are cosets irrelevant to?
What does group element g define?

context: In many situations it is desirable to consider two group elements the same <b3_0>if they differ by an element<b3_0/> of a given subgroup. For example, in D4 above, <b7_0>once a reflection is performed<b7_0/>, the square never gets back to the r2 configuration by just applying <b4_0>the rotation operations<b4_0/> (and no further reflections), i.e. the <a1_0>rotation operations<a1_0/> are <a0_0>irrelevant to the question <b5_0>whether a reflection has been performed<b5_0/><a0_0/>. <a2_0>Cosets<a2_0/> are used to formalize this insight: a subgroup H defines <b6_0>left and right cosets<b6_0/>, which can be thought of as translations of H by arbitrary group elements g. In symbolic terms, the left and right cosets of H containing g are
